metadata.Title: CVE-2017-14604 on Ubuntu 21.10 (impish) - low.
metadata.Description:
GNOME Nautilus before 3.23.90 allows attackers to spoof a file type by using the .desktop file extension, as demonstrated by an attack in which a .desktop file's Name field ends in .pdf but this file's Exec field launches a malicious "sh -c" command. In other words, Nautilus provides no UI indication that a file actually has the potentially unsafe .desktop extension; instead, the UI only shows the .pdf extension. One (slightly) mitigating factor is that an attack requires the .desktop file to have execute permission. The solution is to ask the user to confirm that the file is supposed to be treated as a .desktop file, and then remember the user's answer in the metadata::trusted field.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo ua fix CVE-2017-14604` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

gir1.2-nautilus-3.0 - 1:3.26.0-0ubuntu1
libnautilus-extension1a - 1:3.26.0-0ubuntu1
nautilus - 1:3.26.0-0ubuntu1
nautilus-data - 1:3.26.0-0ubuntu1
No subscription required

notes.Note: mdeslaur> fixing this in stable releases would result in the user getting an unexpected "Untrusted application launcher" dialog on existing .desktop files. Dialog changes would also need new translations.

criterions.comment: nautilus package in impish, is related to the CVE in some way and has been fixed (note: '1:3.26.0-0ubuntu1').
